statement.tex: \text{For the function } f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} = \sqrt{5x-2x^2} \\ \text{find the following} \\ \text{(a) its domain. }\\ \text{(b) domain if }f:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{R}\text{ instead of }f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}.

step.context: \textbf{A question on notation.} \\ \text{The table below shows some function}\\ \text{notations and what they mean.} \\ \textbf{But is everything in the table correct?}
step.tex: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Notation} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline f(x) = f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{N} & x\in\mathbb{R}, f(x)\in\mathbb{N} \\ \hline f(x) = f:\mathbb{Z}\to\mathbb{N} & x\in\mathbb{Z}, f(x)\in\mathbb{N} \\ \hline f(x) = f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} & x\in\mathbb{R}, f(x)\in\mathbb{R} \\ \hline \end{tabular}

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Notation} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline f(x) = f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{N} & x\in\mathbb{N}, f(x)\in\mathbb{R} \\ \hline f(x) = f:\mathbb{Z}\to\mathbb{N} & x\in\mathbb{N}, f(x)\in\mathbb{Z} \\ \hline f(x) = f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} & x\in\mathbb{R}, f(x)\in\mathbb{R} \\ \hline \end{tabular}
step.reason: f(x) = f:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{R}\text{ - for example - means that} \\ \text{the domain of f(x) is the set of natural numbers.}\\ \text{But f(x) itself }\in\mathbb{R}. \\ \text{Hence, the correct table will be} \\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline \text{Notation} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline f(x) = f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{N} & x\in\mathbb{R}, f(x)\in\mathbb{N} \\ \hline f(x) = f:\mathbb{Z}\to\mathbb{N} & x\in\mathbb{Z}, f(x)\in\mathbb{N} \\ \hline f(x) = f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} & x\in\mathbb{R}, f(x)\in\mathbb{R} \\ \hline \end{tabular}

\text{For f(x) to be defined, }\\ \quad 5x-2x^2\geq 0\implies x\cdot (5-2x)\geq 0.\\ \text{This gives rise to the following cases.}\\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline & x & 5-2x & x\cdot(5-2x) \\ \hline x\lt 0 & - & + & - \\ \hline 0\leq x\leq \frac{5}{2} & + & + & + \\ \hline x\gt\frac{5}{2} & + & - & - \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ \text{As }5x-2x^2\geq 0\text{ only when }0\leq x\leq\frac{5}{2}\\ \text{the domain of f(x) is }\left[0,\frac{5}{2}\right].

step.context: \textbf{Right or wrong?}\\ \text{The domain of }f:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}\text{ is }\left[0,\frac{5}{2}\right].\\ \text{But if it was }f:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{R},\text{ then the following}\\ \text{would have been true.}
step.reason: \text{If the function were now }f:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{R},\text{then}\\ \text{only }x\in\mathbb{N}\text{ can be in the domain.}\\ \text{So, how many natural numbers are there}\\ \text{in }\left[0,\frac{5}{2}\right]=\left[0,2.5\right]?\\ \text{Just two - 1 and 2. (No, }0\notin\mathbb{N}).\\ \text{Hence, the domain now is }\lbrace 1,2\rbrace.
